title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. I have drunk poison whiles he utter'd it.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. But did my brother set thee on to this?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bora. Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. He is compos'd and fram'd of treachery,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And fled he is upon this villany.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: In the rare semblance that I lov'd it first.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Dog. Come, bring away the plaintiffs. By this time our sexton hath

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: reformed Signior Leonato of the matter. And, masters, do not

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: forget to specify, when time and place shall serve, that I am an

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: ass.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Verg. Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the sexton too.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Leonato, his brother [Antonio], and the Sexton.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: That, when I note another man like him,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: I may avoid him. Which of these is he?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bora. If you would know your wronger, look on me.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast kill'd

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Mine innocent child?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bora. Yea, even I alone.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. No, not so, villain! thou beliest thyself.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Here stand a pair of honourable men--

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: A third is fled--that had a hand in it.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: I thank you princes for my daughter's death.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Record it with your high and worthy deeds.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: 'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. I know not how to pray your patience;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Impose me to what penance your invention

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Can lay upon my sin. Yet sinn'd I not

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: But in mistaking.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. By my soul, nor I!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And yet, to satisfy this good old man,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: I would bend under any heavy weight

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: That he'll enjoin me to.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. I cannot bid you bid my daughter live-

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: That were impossible; but I pray you both,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Possess the people in Messina here

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: How innocent she died; and if your love

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Can labour aught in sad invention,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And sing it to her bones--sing it to-night.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: To-morrow morning come you to my house,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And since you could not be my son-in-law,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Be yet my nephew. My brother hath a daughter,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Almost the copy of my child that's dead,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And she alone is heir to both of us.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Give her the right you should have giv'n her cousin,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And so dies my revenge.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. O noble sir!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Your over-kindness doth wring tears from me.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: I do embrace your offer; and dispose

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: For henceforth of poor Claudio.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. To-morrow then I will expect your coming;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: To-night I take my leave. This naughty man

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Shall fact to face be brought to Margaret,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Who I believe was pack'd in all this wrong,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Hir'd to it by your brother.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bora. No, by my soul, she was not;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: But always hath been just and virtuous

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: In anything that I do know by her.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Dog. Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under white and black, this

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: plaintiff here, the offender, did call me ass. I beseech you let

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: it be rememb'red in his punishment. And also the watch heard them

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: talk of one Deformed. They say he wears a key in his ear, and a

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: lock hanging by it, and borrows money in God's name, the which he

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: hath us'd so long and never paid that now men grow hard-hearted

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: and will lend nothing for God's sake. Pray you examine him upon

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: that point.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Dog. Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: and I praise God for you.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. There's for thy pains. [Gives money.]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Dog. God save the foundation!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Dog. I leave an arrant knave with your worship, which I beseech

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: your worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: God keep your worship! I wish your worship well. God restore you

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: to health! I humbly give you leave to depart; and if a merry

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: meeting may be wish'd, God prohibit it! Come, neighbour.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Exeunt [Dogberry and Verges].

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Until to-morrow morning, lords, farewell.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Ant. Farewell, my lords. We look for you to-morrow.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. We will not fall.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. To-night I'll mourn with Hero.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: [Exeunt Don Pedro and Claudio.]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. [to the Watch] Bring you these fellows on.--We'll talk with

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Margaret,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Exeunt.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Scene II.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leonato's orchard.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Benedick and Margaret [meeting].

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my hands

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Marg. Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shall come

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: over it; for in most comely truth thou deservest it.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Marg. To have no man come over me? Why, shall I always keep below

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: stairs?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound's mouth--it catches.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Marg. And yours as blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit but hurt

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: not.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. A most manly wit, Margaret: it will not hurt a woman.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And so I pray thee call Beatrice. I give thee the bucklers.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Marg. Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our own.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with a

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: vice, and they are dangerous weapons for maids.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Marg. Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. And therefore will come.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Exit Margaret.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: [Sings] The god of love,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: That sits above

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And knows me, and knows me,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: How pitiful I deserve--

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: I mean in singing; but in loving Leander the good swimmer,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Troilus the first employer of panders, and a whole book full of

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: these quondam carpet-mongers, whose names yet run smoothly in the

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: even road of a blank verse--why, they were never so truly turn'd

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: over and over as my poor self in love. Marry, I cannot show it in

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: rhyme. I have tried. I can find out no rhyme to 'lady' but

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: 'baby'

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: --an innocent rhyme; for 'scorn,' 'horn'--a hard rhyme; for

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: 'school', 'fool'--a babbling rhyme: very ominous endings! No, I

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: was not born under a rhyming planet, nor cannot woo in festival

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: terms.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Beatrice.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I call'd thee?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Yea, signior, and depart when you bid me.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. O, stay but till then!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. 'Then' is spoken. Fare you well now. And yet, ere I go, let

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: me go with that I came for, which is, with knowing what hath

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: pass'd between you and Claudio.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Only foul words; and thereupon I will kiss thee.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: breath, and foul breath is noisome. Therefore I will depart

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: unkiss'd.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: undergoes my challenge; and either I must shortly hear from him

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: or I will subscribe him a coward. And I pray thee now tell me,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. For them all together, which maintain'd so politic a state of

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: them. But for which of my good parts did you first suffer love

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: for me?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Suffer love!--a good epithet. I do suffer love indeed, for I

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: love thee against my will.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. In spite of your heart, I think. Alas, poor heart! If you

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: spite it for my sake, I will spite it for yours, for I will never

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: love that which my friend hates.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. It appears not in this confession. There's not one wise man

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: among twenty, that will praise himself.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that liv'd in the time of

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: good neighbours. If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than the bell

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: rings and the widow weeps.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. And how long is that, think you?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Question: why, an hour in clamour and a quarter in rheum.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm (his

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: conscience) find no impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: of his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much for praising

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is praiseworthy. And now

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: tell me, how doth your cousin?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Very ill.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. And how do you?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Very ill too.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Serve God, love me, and mend. There will I leave you too, for

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: here comes one in haste.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Ursula.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Urs. Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder's old coil at home.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accus'd, the Prince

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: and Claudio mightily abus'd, and Don John is the author of all,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: who is fled and gone. Will you come presently?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Will you go hear this news, signior?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried thy

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: eyes; and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncle's.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Exeunt.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Scene III.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: A churchyard.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Claudio, Don Pedro, and three or four with tapers,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: [followed by Musicians].

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. Is this the monument of Leonato?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Lord. It is, my lord.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. [reads from a scroll]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Epitaph.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Done to death by slanderous tongues

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Was the Hero that here lies.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Gives her fame which never dies.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: So the life that died with shame

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Lives in death with glorious fame.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Hang thou there upon the tomb,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: [Hangs up the scroll.]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Praising her when I am dumb.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Song.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pardon, goddess of the night,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Those that slew thy virgin knight;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: For the which, with songs of woe,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Round about her tomb they go.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Midnight, assist our moan,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Help us to sigh and groan

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Heavily, heavily,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Graves, yawn and yield your dead,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Till death be uttered

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Heavily, heavily.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. Now unto thy bones good night!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Yearly will I do this rite.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. Good morrow, masters. Put your torches out.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: The wolves have prey'd, and look, the gentle day,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Thanks to you all, and leave us. Fare you well.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. Good morrow, masters. Each his several way.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. Come, let us hence and put on other weeds,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And then to Leonato's we will go.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. And Hymen now with luckier issue speeds

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Than this for whom we rend'red up this woe.          Exeunt.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Scene IV

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: The hall in Leonato's house.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Leonato, Benedick, [Beatrice,] Margaret, Ursula, Antonio,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Friar [Francis], Hero.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Friar. Did I not tell you she was innocent?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. So are the Prince and Claudio, who accus'd her

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Upon the error that you heard debated.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: But Margaret was in some fault for this,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Although against her will, as it appears

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: In the true course of all the question.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Ant. Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. And so am I, being else by faith enforc'd

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And when I send for you, come hither mask'd.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Exeunt Ladies.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: The Prince and Claudio promis'd by this hour

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: To visit me. You know your office, brother:

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: You must be father to your brother's daughter,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And give her to young Claudio.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Ant. Which I will do with confirm'd countenance.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Friar. To do what, signior?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. To bind me, or undo me--one of them.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. That eye my daughter lent her. 'Tis most true.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. And I do with an eye of love requite her.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. The sight whereof I think you had from me,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: From Claudio, and the Prince; but what's your will?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Your answer, sir, is enigmatical;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: But, for my will, my will is, your good will

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin'd

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: In the state of honourable marriage;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. My heart is with your liking.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Friar. And my help.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Don Pedro and Claudio and two or three other.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. Good morrow to this fair assembly.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: We here attend you. Are you yet determin'd

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: To-day to marry with my brother's daughter?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. I'll hold my mind, were she an Ethiope.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Call her forth, brother. Here's the friar ready.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: [Exit Antonio.]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what's the matter

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: That you have such a February face,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: So full of frost, of storm, and cloudiness?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. I think he thinks upon the savage bull.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Tush, fear not, man! We'll tip thy horns with gold,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: As once Europa did at lusty Jove

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: When he would play the noble beast in love.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And some such strange bull leap'd your father's cow

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And got a calf in that same noble feat

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter [Leonato's] brother [Antonio], Hero, Beatrice,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Margaret, Ursula, [the ladies wearing masks].

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. For this I owe you. Here comes other reckonings.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Which is the lady I must seize upon?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Ant. This same is she, and I do give you her.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. Why then, she's mine. Sweet, let me see your face.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. No, that you shall not till you take her hand

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Before this friar and swear to marry her.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. Give me your hand before this holy friar.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: I am your husband if you like of me.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Hero. And when I liv'd I was your other wife;       [Unmasks.]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And when you lov'd you were my other husband.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. Another Hero!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Hero. Nothing certainer.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: One Hero died defil'd; but I do live,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And surely as I live, I am a maid.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Pedro. The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. She died, my lord, but whiles her slander liv'd.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Friar. All this amazement can I qualify,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: When, after that the holy rites are ended,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Meantime let wonder seem familiar,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And to the chapel let us presently.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. [unmasks] I answer to that name. What is your will?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Do not you love me?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Why, no; no more than reason.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Why, then your uncle, and the Prince, and Claudio

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Have been deceived; for they swore you did.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Do not you love me?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Troth, no; no more than reason.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. Why, then my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Are much deceiv'd; for they did swear you did.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. They swore that you were almost sick for me.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. 'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. And I'll be sworn upon't that he loves her;

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: For here's a paper written in his hand,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Fashion'd to Beatrice.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Hero. And here's another,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Writ in my cousin's hand, stol'n from her pocket,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Containing her affection unto Benedick.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. A miracle! Here's our own hands against our hearts.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Come, I will have thee; but, by this light, I take thee for pity.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. I would not deny you; but, by this good day, I yield upon

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: you were in a consumption.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Peace! I will stop your mouth.             [Kisses her.]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Beat. I'll tell thee what, Prince: a college of wit-crackers cannot

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: flout me out of my humour. Dost thou think I care for a satire or

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: an epigram? No. If a man will be beaten with brains, 'a shall

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do purpose to

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: marry, I will think nothing to any purpose that the world can say

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: against it; and therefore never flout at me for what I have said

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: against it; for man is a giddy thing, and this is my conclusion.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: For thy part, Claudio, I did think to have beaten thee; but in

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: that thou art like to be my kinsman, live unbruis'd, and love my

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: cousin.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Claud. I had well hop'd thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: might have cudgell'd thee out of thy single life, to make thee a

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: double-dealer, which out of question thou wilt be if my cousin do

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: not look exceeding narrowly to thee.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Come, come, we are friends. Let's have a dance ere we are

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: married, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives' heels.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Leon. We'll have dancing afterward.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. First, of my word! Therefore play, music. Prince, thou art

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: sad. Get thee a wife, get thee a wife! There is no staff more

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: reverent than one tipp'd with horn.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Enter Messenger.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Mess. My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight,

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: And brought with armed men back to Messina.

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Bene. Think not on him till to-morrow. I'll devise thee brave

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: punishments for him. Strike up, pipers!

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: Dance. [Exeunt.]

title: Much Ado about Nothing
text: THE END

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: SCENE: Scotland and England

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: ACT I. SCENE I.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: A desert place. Thunder and lightning.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Enter three Witches.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: FIRST WITCH. When shall we three meet again?

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: In thunder, lightning, or in rain?

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: SECOND WITCH. When the hurlyburly's done,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: When the battle's lost and won.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: THIRD WITCH. That will be ere the set of sun.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: FIRST WITCH. Where the place?

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: SECOND WITCH. Upon the heath.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: THIRD WITCH. There to meet with Macbeth.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: FIRST WITCH. I come, Graymalkin.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: ALL. Paddock calls. Anon!

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Fair is foul, and foul is fair.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Hover through the fog and filthy air.                Exeunt.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: SCENE II.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: A camp near Forres. Alarum within.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Enter Duncan, Malcolm, Donalbain, Lennox, with Attendants,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: meeting a bleeding Sergeant.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: DUNCAN. What bloody man is that? He can report,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: As seemeth by his plight, of the revolt

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: The newest state.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: MALCOLM. This is the sergeant

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Who like a good and hardy soldier fought

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: 'Gainst my captivity. Hail, brave friend!

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Say to the King the knowledge of the broil

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: As thou didst leave it.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: SERGEANT. Doubtful it stood,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: As two spent swimmers that do cling together

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: And choke their art. The merciless Macdonwald-

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Worthy to be a rebel, for to that

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: The multiplying villainies of nature

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Do swarm upon him -from the Western Isles

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Of kerns and gallowglasses is supplied;

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: And Fortune, on his damned quarrel smiling,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Show'd like a rebel's whore. But all's too weak;

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: For brave Macbeth -well he deserves that name-

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Disdaining Fortune, with his brandish'd steel,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Which smoked with bloody execution,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Like Valor's minion carved out his passage

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Till he faced the slave,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Which ne'er shook hands, nor bade farewell to him,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Till he unseam'd him from the nave to the chaps,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: And fix'd his head upon our battlements.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: DUNCAN. O valiant cousin! Worthy gentleman!

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: SERGEANT. As whence the sun 'gins his reflection

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Shipwrecking storms and direful thunders break,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: So from that spring whence comfort seem'd to come

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Discomfort swells. Mark, King of Scotland, mark.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: No sooner justice had, with valor arm'd,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Compell'd these skipping kerns to trust their heels,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: But the Norweyan lord, surveying vantage,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: With furbish'd arms and new supplies of men,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Began a fresh assault.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: DUNCAN. Dismay'd not this

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Our captains, Macbeth and Banquo.?

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: SERGEANT. Yes,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: As sparrows eagles, or the hare the lion.

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: If I say sooth, I must report they were

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: As cannons overcharged with double cracks,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: So they

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth

text: In such an honor named. What's more to do,

text: As calling home our exiled friends abroad

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: That fled the snares of watchful tyranny,

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth

title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
text: Of this dead butcher and his fiend-like queen,

text: Took off her life; this, and what needful else

text: Whom we invite to see us crown'd at Scone.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: ACT I.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: SCENE I. Athens. A room in the Palace of THESEUS.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and Attendants.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Draws on apace; four happy days bring in

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Another moon; but, oh, methinks, how slow

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: This old moon wanes! she lingers my desires,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Like to a step-dame or a dowager,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Long withering out a young man's revenue.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HIPPOLYTA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Four days will quickly steep themselves in nights;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Four nights will quickly dream away the time;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And then the moon, like to a silver bow

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: New bent in heaven, shall behold the night

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Of our solemnities.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Go, Philostrate,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Turn melancholy forth to funerals--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The pale companion is not for our pomp. --

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exit PHILOSTRATE.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Hippolyta, I woo'd thee with my sword,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And won thy love doing thee injuries;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But I will wed thee in another key,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With pomp, with triumph, and with revelling.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: EGEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Happy be Theseus, our renowned duke!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thanks, good Egeus: what's the news with thee?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: EGEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Full of vexation come I, with complaint

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Against my child, my daughter Hermia.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Stand forth, Demetrius.--My noble lord,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: This man hath my consent to marry her:--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Stand forth, Lysander;--and, my gracious duke,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: This man hath bewitch'd the bosom of my child.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And interchang'd love-tokens with my child:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With feigning voice, verses of feigning love;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And stol'n the impression of her fantasy

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gawds, conceits,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats,--messengers

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Of strong prevailment in unharden'd youth;--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With cunning hast thou filch'd my daughter's heart;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Turned her obedience, which is due to me,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To stubborn harshness.--And, my gracious duke,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Be it so she will not here before your grace

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Consent to marry with Demetrius,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I beg the ancient privilege of Athens,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As she is mine I may dispose of her:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Which shall be either to this gentleman

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or to her death; according to our law

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Immediately provided in that case.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: What say you, Hermia? be advis'd, fair maid:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To you your father should be as a god;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: One that compos'd your beauties: yea, and one

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To whom you are but as a form in wax,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By him imprinted, and within his power

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To leave the figure, or disfigure it.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: So is Lysander.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In himself he is:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But, in this kind, wanting your father's voice,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The other must be held the worthier.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I would my father look'd but with my eyes.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I do entreat your grace to pardon me.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I know not by what power I am made bold,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Nor how it may concern my modesty

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In such a presence here to plead my thoughts:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But I beseech your grace that I may know

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The worst that may befall me in this case

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: If I refuse to wed Demetrius.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Either to die the death, or to abjure

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For ever the society of men.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Know of your youth, examine well your blood,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Whether, if you yield not to your father's choice,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You can endure the livery of a nun;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For aye to be shady cloister mew'd,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To live a barren sister all your life,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Chanting faint hymns to the cold, fruitless moon.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thrice-blessed they that master so their blood

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To undergo such maiden pilgrimage:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But earthlier happy is the rose distill'd

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Than that which, withering on the virgin thorn,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Grows, lives, and dies, in single blessedness.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ere I will yield my virgin patent up

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Unto his lordship, whose unwished yoke

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: My soul consents not to give sovereignty.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Take time to pause; and by the next new moon,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The sealing-day betwixt my love and me

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For everlasting bond of fellowship,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Upon that day either prepare to die

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For disobedience to your father's will;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or on Diana's altar to protest

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For aye austerity and single life.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: DEMETRIUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Relent, sweet Hermia;--and, Lysander, yield

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thy crazed title to my certain right.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You have her father's love, Demetrius;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Let me have Hermia's: do you marry him.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: EGEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Scornful Lysander! true, he hath my love;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And what is mine my love shall render him;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And she is mine; and all my right of her

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I do estate unto Demetrius.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I am, my lord, as well deriv'd as he,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As well possess'd; my love is more than his;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: If not with vantage, as Demetrius's;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And, which is more than all these boasts can be,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I am belov'd of beauteous Hermia:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Why should not I then prosecute my right?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Demetrius, I'll avouch it to his head,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Made love to Nedar's daughter, Helena,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, dotes,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Upon this spotted and inconstant man.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I must confess that I have heard so much,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But, being over-full of self-affairs,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: My mind did lose it.--But, Demetrius, come;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And come, Egeus; you shall go with me;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I have some private schooling for you both.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To fit your fancies to your father's will,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or else the law of Athens yields you up,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Which by no means we may extenuate,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To death, or to a vow of single life.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Come, my Hippolyta: what cheer, my love?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Demetrius, and Egeus, go along;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I must employ you in some business

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Against our nuptial, and confer with you

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: EGEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With duty and desire we follow you.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, DEMETRIUS, and Train.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: How now, my love! why is your cheek so pale?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: How chance the roses there do fade so fast?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Belike for want of rain, which I could well

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ah me! for aught that I could ever read,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Could ever hear by tale or history,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The course of true love never did run smooth:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But either it was different in blood,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O cross! Too high to be enthrall'd to low!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or else misgraffed in respect of years;--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O spite! Too old to be engag'd to young!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O hell! to choose love by another's eye!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or, if there were a sympathy in choice,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: War, death, or sickness, did lay siege to it,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Making it momentary as a sound,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Swift as a shadow, short as any dream;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Brief as the lightning in the collied night

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and earth,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And ere a man hath power to say, Behold!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The jaws of darkness do devour it up:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: So quick bright things come to confusion.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: If then true lovers have ever cross'd,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: It stands as an edict in destiny:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Then let us teach our trial patience,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Because it is a customary cross;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As due to love as thoughts, and dreams, and sighs,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Wishes and tears, poor fancy's followers.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: A good persuasion; therefore, hear me, Hermia.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I have a widow aunt, a dowager

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Of great revenue, and she hath no child:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And she respects me as her only son.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And to that place the sharp Athenian law

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Cannot pursue us. If thou lovest me then,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Steal forth thy father's house tomorrow night;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And in the wood, a league without the town,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Where I did meet thee once with Helena,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To do observance to a morn of May,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: There will I stay for thee.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: My good Lysander!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I swear to thee by Cupid's strongest bow,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By his best arrow, with the golden head,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By the simplicity of Venus' doves,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And by that fire which burn'd the Carthage queen,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: When the false Trojan under sail was seen,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By all the vows that ever men have broke,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In number more than ever women spoke,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In that same place thou hast appointed me,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Tomorrow truly will I meet with thee.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Keep promise, love. Look, here comes Helena.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter HELENA.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: God speed fair Helena! Whither away?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HELENA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Call you me fair? that fair again unsay.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Demetrius loves your fair. O happy fair!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Your eyes are lode-stars; and your tongue's sweet air

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: More tuneable than lark to shepherd's ear,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Sickness is catching: O, were favour so,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: My ear should catch your voice, my eye your eye,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: My tongue should catch your tongue's sweet melody.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The rest I'd give to be to you translated.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O, teach me how you look; and with what art

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HELENA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HELENA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O that my prayers could such affection move!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The more I hate, the more he follows me.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HELENA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The more I love, the more he hateth me.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HELENA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: None, but your beauty: would that fault were mine!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Take comfort; he no more shall see my face;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Lysander and myself will fly this place.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Before the time I did Lysander see,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Seem'd Athens as a paradise to me:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O, then, what graces in my love do dwell,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That he hath turn'd a heaven unto hell!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To-morrow night, when Phoebe doth behold

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Her silver visage in the watery glass,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Through Athens' gates have we devis'd to steal.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HERMIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And in the wood where often you and I

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Upon faint primrose beds were wont to lie,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: There my Lysander and myself shall meet:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And thence from Athens turn away our eyes,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To seek new friends and stranger companies.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Farewell, sweet playfellow: pray thou for us,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius!--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Keep word, Lysander: we must starve our sight

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: From lovers' food, till morrow deep midnight.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I will, my Hermia.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exit HERMIA.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: LYSANDER

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Helena, adieu:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exit LYSANDER.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: HELENA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: How happy some o'er other some can be!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: He will not know what all but he do know.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And as he errs, doting on Hermia's eyes,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: So I, admiring of his qualities.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Things base and vile, holding no quantity,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Love can transpose to form and dignity.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And therefore is wing'd Cupid painted blind.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Nor hath love's mind of any judgment taste;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And therefore is love said to be a child,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Because in choice he is so oft beguil'd.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As waggish boys in game themselves forswear,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: So the boy Love is perjur'd everywhere:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For ere Demetrius look'd on Hermia's eyne,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: He hail'd down oaths that he was only mine;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: So he dissolv'd, and showers of oaths did melt.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I will go tell him of fair Hermia's flight;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Then to the wood will he to-morrow night

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Pursue her; and for this intelligence

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: If I have thanks, it is a dear expense:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But herein mean I to enrich my pain,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To have his sight thither and back again.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exit HELENA.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: SCENE II. The Same. A Room in a Cottage.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, QUINCE, and STARVELING.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Is all our company here?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You were best to call them generally, man by man,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: according to the scrip.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Here is the scroll of every man's name, which is thought

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: fit, through all Athens, to play in our interlude before the

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: duke and duchess on his wedding-day at night.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: then read the names of the actors; and so grow to a point.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Marry, our play is--The most lamentable comedy and most

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: cruel death of Pyramus and Thisby.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a merry.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your actors by the scroll.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Masters, spread yourselves.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Answer, as I call you.--Nick Bottom, the weaver.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: What is Pyramus? a lover, or a tyrant?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: A lover, that kills himself most gallantly for love.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That will ask some tears in the true performing of it.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: If I do it, let the audience look to their eyes; I will move

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: storms; I will condole in some measure. To the rest:--yet my

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: chief humour is for a tyrant: I could play Ercles rarely, or a

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: part to tear a cat in, to make all split.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The raging rocks

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And shivering shocks

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Shall break the locks

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Of prison gates:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And Phibbus' car

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Shall shine from far,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And make and mar

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The foolish Fates.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: This was lofty.--Now name the rest of the players.--This is

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein;--a lover is more condoling.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: FLUTE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Here, Peter Quince.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Flute, you must take Thisby on you.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: FLUTE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: What is Thisby? a wandering knight?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: FLUTE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Nay, faith, let not me play a woman; I have a beard coming.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That's all one; you shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: small as you will.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisby too:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I'll speak in a monstrous little voice;--'Thisne, Thisne!'--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: 'Ah, Pyramus, my lover dear; thy Thisby dear! and lady dear!'

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: No, no, you must play Pyramus; and, Flute, you Thisby.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Well, proceed.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Robin Starveling, the tailor.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: STARVELING

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Here, Peter Quince.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Tom Snout, the tinker.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: SNOUT

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Here, Peter Quince.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You, Pyramus' father; myself, Thisby's father;--Snug,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: the joiner, you, the lion's part:--and, I hope, here is a play

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: fitted.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: SNUG

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Have you the lion's part written? pray you, if it be, give it

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: me, for I am slow of study.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Let me play the lion too: I will roar that I will do

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar that I will make the

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: duke say 'Let him roar again, let him roar again.'

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: An you should do it too terribly, you would fright the

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: duchess and the ladies, that they would shriek; and that were

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: enough to hang us all.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: ALL

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That would hang us every mother's son.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: us: but I will aggravate my voice so, that I will roar you as

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: gently as any sucking dove; I will roar you an 'twere any

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: nightingale.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You can play no part but Pyramus; for Pyramus is a

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: sweet-faced man; a proper man, as one shall see in a summer's

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: day; a most lovely gentleman-like man; therefore you must

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: needs play Pyramus.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best to play it in?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Why, what you will.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I will discharge it in either your straw-colour beard,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: French-crown-colour beard, your perfect yellow.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: then you will play bare-faced.-- But, masters, here are your

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: parts: and I am to entreat you, request you, and desire you, to

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: con them by to-morrow night; and meet me in the palace wood, a

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: mile without the town, by moonlight; there will we rehearse: for

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: if we meet in the city, we shall be dogg'd with company, and our

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: devices known. In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: such as our play wants. I pray you, fail me not.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: We will meet; and there we may rehearse most obscenely

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: and courageously. Take pains; be perfect; adieu.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: QUINCE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: At the duke's oak we meet.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Enough; hold, or cut bow-strings.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exeunt.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: ACT II.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter a FAIRY at One door, and PUCK at another.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: PUCK

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: How now, spirit! whither wander you?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: FAIRY

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Over hill, over dale,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thorough bush, thorough brier,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Over park, over pale,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thorough flood, thorough fire,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I do wander everywhere,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Swifter than the moon's sphere;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And I serve the fairy queen,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To dew her orbs upon the green.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The cowslips tall her pensioners be:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In their gold coats spots you see;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Those be rubies, fairy favours,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In those freckles live their savours;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I must go seek some dew-drops here,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Farewell, thou lob of spirits; I'll be gone:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Our queen and all her elves come here anon.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: PUCK

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The king doth keep his revels here to-night;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Take heed the Queen come not within his sight.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Because that she, as her attendant, hath

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: A lovely boy, stol'n from an Indian king;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: She never had so sweet a changeling:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And jealous Oberon would have the child

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But she perforce withholds the loved boy,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Crowns him with flowers, and makes him all her joy:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And now they never meet in grove or green,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By fountain clear, or spangled starlight sheen,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But they do square; that all their elves for fear

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Creep into acorn cups, and hide them there.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: FAIRY

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Either I mistake your shape and making quite,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Call'd Robin Goodfellow: are not you he

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That frights the maidens of the villagery;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And bootless make the breathless housewife churn;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And sometime make the drink to bear no barm;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Those that Hobgoblin call you, and sweet Puck,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: You do their work, and they shall have good luck:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Are not you he?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: PUCK

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thou speak'st aright;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I am that merry wanderer of the night.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I jest to Oberon, and make him smile,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Neighing in likeness of a filly foal;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And sometime lurk I in a gossip's bowl,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In very likeness of a roasted crab;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And, when she drinks, against her lips I bob,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And 'tailor' cries, and falls into a cough;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And then the whole quire hold their hips and loffe,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: A merrier hour was never wasted there.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But room, fairy, here comes Oberon.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: FAIRY

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And here my mistress.--Would that he were gone!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter OBERON at one door, with his Train, and TITANIA,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: at another, with hers.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: OBERON

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: TITANIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: What, jealous Oberon! Fairies, skip hence;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I have forsworn his bed and company.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: OBERON

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Tarry, rash wanton: am not I thy lord?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: TITANIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Then I must be thy lady; but I know

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: When thou hast stol'n away from fairy-land,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And in the shape of Corin sat all day,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Playing on pipes of corn, and versing love

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To amorous Phillida. Why art thou here,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Come from the farthest steep of India,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Your buskin'd mistress and your warrior love,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To Theseus must be wedded; and you come

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To give their bed joy and prosperity.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: OBERON

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: How canst thou thus, for shame, Titania,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Glance at my credit with Hippolyta,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Didst not thou lead him through the glimmering night

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: From Perigenia, whom he ravish'd?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And make him with fair Aegle break his faith,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With Ariadne and Antiopa?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: TITANIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: These are the forgeries of jealousy:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And never, since the middle summer's spring,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Met we on hill, in dale, forest, or mead,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By paved fountain, or by rushy brook,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Or on the beached margent of the sea,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But with thy brawls thou hast disturb'd our sport.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As in revenge, have suck'd up from the sea

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Contagious fogs; which, falling in the land,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Hath every pelting river made so proud

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That they have overborne their continents:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The ox hath therefore stretch'd his yoke in vain,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The ploughman lost his sweat; and the green corn

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Hath rotted ere his youth attain'd a beard:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The fold stands empty in the drowned field,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And crows are fatted with the murrion flock;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The nine men's morris is fill'd up with mud;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And the quaint mazes in the wanton green,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: For lack of tread, are undistinguishable:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The human mortals want their winter here;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: No night is now with hymn or carol blest:--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Pale in her anger, washes all the air,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That rheumatic diseases do abound:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And thorough this distemperature we see

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Fall in the fresh lap of the crimson rose;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And on old Hyem's thin and icy crown

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Is, as in mockery, set: the spring, the summer,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The childing autumn, angry winter, change

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Their wonted liveries; and the maz'd world,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By their increase, now knows not which is which:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And this same progeny of evils comes

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: From our debate, from our dissension:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: We are their parents and original.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: OBERON

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Do you amend it, then: it lies in you:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I do but beg a little changeling boy

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To be my henchman.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: TITANIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Set your heart at rest;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The fairy-land buys not the child of me.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: His mother was a vot'ress of my order:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And, in the spiced Indian air, by night,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Full often hath she gossip'd by my side;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And sat with me on Neptune's yellow sands,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Marking the embarked traders on the flood;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: When we have laugh'd to see the sails conceive,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Following,--her womb then rich with my young squire,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Would imitate; and sail upon the land,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To fetch me trifles, and return again,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: But she, being mortal, of that boy did die;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And for her sake do I rear up her boy:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And for her sake I will not part with him.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: OBERON
