text: DEMETRIUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And thus she moans, videlicet.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THISBE

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Asleep, my love?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: What, dead, my dove?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O Pyramus, arise,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Speak, speak. Quite dumb?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Dead, dead? A tomb

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Must cover thy sweet eyes.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: These lily lips,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: This cherry nose,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: These yellow cowslip cheeks,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Are gone, are gone:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Lovers, make moan!

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: His eyes were green as leeks.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: O Sisters Three,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Come, come to me,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With hands as pale as milk;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Lay them in gore,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Since you have shore

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With shears his thread of silk.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Tongue, not a word:--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Come, trusty sword;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Come, blade, my breast imbrue;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And farewell, friends:--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Thus Thisbe ends;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Adieu, adieu, adieu.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Dies.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Moonshine and lion are left to bury the dead.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: DEMETRIUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ay, and wall too.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: BOTTOM

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: No, I assure you; the wall is down that parted their fathers.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Will it please you to see the epilogue, or to hear a Bergomask

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: dance between two of our company?

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: THESEUS

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: No epilogue, I pray you; for your play needs no

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: excuse. Never excuse; for when the players are all dead there

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: need none to be blamed. Marry, if he that writ it had played

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Pyramus, and hang'd himself in Thisbe's garter, it would have

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: been a fine tragedy: and so it is, truly; and very notably

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: discharged. But come, your Bergomask; let your epilogue alone.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Here a dance of Clowns.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve:--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Lovers, to bed; 'tis almost fairy time.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I fear we shall out-sleep the coming morn,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: As much as we this night have overwatch'd.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: This palpable-gross play hath well beguil'd

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: The heavy gait of night.--Sweet friends, to bed.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: A fortnight hold we this solemnity,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In nightly revels and new jollity.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exeunt.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: SCENE II

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter PUCK.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: PUCK

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Now the hungry lion roars,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And the wolf behowls the moon;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Whilst the heavy ploughman snores,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: All with weary task fordone.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Now the wasted brands do glow,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Whilst the scritch-owl, scritching loud,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Puts the wretch that lies in woe

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In remembrance of a shroud.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Now it is the time of night

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That the graves, all gaping wide,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Every one lets forth its sprite,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: In the church-way paths to glide:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And we fairies, that do run

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By the triple Hecate's team

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: From the presence of the sun,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Following darkness like a dream,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Now are frolic; not a mouse

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Shall disturb this hallow'd house:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: I am sent with broom before,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To sweep the dust behind the door.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Enter OBERON and TITANIA, with their Train.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: OBERON

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Through the house give glimmering light,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: By the dead and drowsy fire:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Every elf and fairy sprite

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Hop as light as bird from brier:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And this ditty, after me,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Sing and dance it trippingly.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: TITANIA

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: First, rehearse your song by rote,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To each word a warbling note;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Hand in hand, with fairy grace,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Will we sing, and bless this place.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Song and Dance.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: OBERON

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Now, until the break of day,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Through this house each fairy stray,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: To the best bride-bed will we,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Which by us shall blessed be;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And the issue there create

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ever shall be fortunate.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: So shall all the couples three

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Ever true in loving be;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And the blots of Nature's hand

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Shall not in their issue stand:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Never mole, hare-lip, nor scar,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Nor mark prodigious, such as are

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Despised in nativity,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Shall upon their children be.--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: With this field-dew consecrate,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Every fairy take his gate;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And each several chamber bless,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Through this palace, with sweet peace;

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: E'er shall it in safety rest,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: And the owner of it blest.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Trip away:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Make no stay:

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Meet me all by break of day.

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: [Exeunt OBERON, TITANIA, and Train.]

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: PUCK

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: If we shadows have offended,

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: Think but this,--and all is mended,--

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
text: That you have but slumber'd here

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: fiend. 'For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,' says the fiend

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'and run.' Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: heart, says very wisely to me 'My honest friend Launcelot, being

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: an honest man's son'--or rather 'an honest woman's son';--for

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: indeed my father did something smack, something grow to, he had a

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: kind of taste;--well, my conscience says 'Launcelot, budge not.'

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'Budge,' says the fiend. 'Budge not,' says my conscience.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'Conscience,' say I, (you counsel well.' 'Fiend,' say I, 'you

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: counsel well.' To be ruled by my conscience, I should stay with

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark! is a kind of devil;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: and, to run away from the Jew, I should be ruled by the fiend,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: who, saving your reverence! is the devil himself. Certainly the

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Jew is the very devil incarnal; and, in my conscience, my

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: conscience is but a kind of hard conscience, to offer to counsel

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: me to stay with the Jew. The fiend gives the more friendly

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: counsel: I will run, fiend; my heels are at your commandment; I

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: will run.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter OLD GOBBO, with a basket]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Master young man, you, I pray you; which is the way to Master

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Jew's?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Aside] O heavens! This is my true-begotten father, who, being

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: more

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: than sand-blind, high-gravel blind, knows me not: I will try

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: confusions with him.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to Master

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Jew's?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but, at

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: the next turning of all, on your left; marry, at the very next

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: turning, turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew's

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: house.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Be God's sonties, 'twill be a hard way to hit. Can you tell

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: me whether one Launcelot, that dwells with him, dwell with him or

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: no?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Talk you of young Master Launcelot? [Aside] Mark me

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: now; now will I raise the waters. Talk you of young Master

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Launcelot?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: No master, sir, but a poor man's son; his father, though I

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: say't, is an honest exceeding poor man, and, God be thanked, well

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: to live.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Well, let his father be what 'a will, we talk of young

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Master Launcelot.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Your worship's friend, and Launcelot, sir.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: you of young Master Launcelot?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Of Launcelot, an't please your mastership.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Ergo, Master Launcelot. Talk not of Master Launcelot,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: father; for the young gentleman,--according to Fates and

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Destinies

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: and such odd sayings, the Sisters Three and such branches of

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: learning,--is indeed deceased; or, as you would say in plain

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: terms, gone to heaven.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Marry, God forbid! The boy was the very staff of my age, my

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: very prop.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?  Do

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: you know me, father?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Alack the day! I know you not, young gentleman; but I pray

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: you tell me, is my boy--God rest his soul!--alive or dead?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Do you not know me, father?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Alack, sir, I am sand-blind; I know you not.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nay, indeed, if you had your eyes, you might fail of the

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: knowing me: it is a wise father that knows his own child. Well,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: old man, I will tell you news of your son. Give me your blessing;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: truth will come to light; murder cannot be hid long; a man's son

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: may, but in the end truth will out.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Pray you, sir, stand up; I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Pray you, let's have no more fooling about it, but give

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: me your blessing; I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: that is, your child that shall be.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I cannot think you are my son.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I know not what I shall think of that; but I am Launcelot, the

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Jew's man, and I am sure Margery your wife is my mother.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Her name is Margery, indeed: I'll be sworn, if thou be

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood. Lord worshipped

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: might he be, what a beard hast thou got! Thou hast got more hair

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: on thy chin than Dobbin my thill-horse has on his tail.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It should seem, then, that Dobbin's tail grows backward;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I am sure he had more hair on his tail than I have on my face

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: when I last saw him.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Lord! how art thou changed! How dost thou and thy master

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: agree? I have brought him a present. How 'gree you now?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Well, well; but, for mine own part, as I have set up my

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: rest to run away, so I will not rest till I have run some ground.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My master's a very Jew. Give him a present! Give him a halter. I

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: am famished in his service; you may tell every finger I have with

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come; give me your present to

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries. If I

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: serve not him, I will run as far as God has any ground. O rare

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: fortune! Here comes the man: to him, father; for I am a Jew, if I

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: serve the Jew any longer.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter BASSANIO, with LEONARDO, with and other Followers.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You may do so; but let it be so hasted that supper be

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: ready at the farthest by five of the clock. See these letters

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: delivered, put the liveries to making, and desire Gratiano to

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: come anon to my lodging.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit a SERVANT]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To him, father.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: God bless your worship!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Gramercy; wouldst thou aught with me?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Here's my son, sir, a poor boy--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man, that would,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: sir,--as my father shall specify--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Indeed the short and the long is, I serve the Jew, and

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: have a desire, as my father shall specify--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: His master and he, saving your worship's reverence, are

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: scarce cater-cousins--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: me wrong, doth cause me,--as my father, being I hope an old man,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: shall frutify unto you--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I have here a dish of doves that I would bestow upon your

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: worship; and my suit is--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: your worship shall know by this honest old man; and, though I say

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: it, though old man, yet poor man, my father.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: One speak for both. What would you?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Serve you, sir.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GOBBO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I know thee well; thou hast obtain'd thy suit.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Shylock thy master spoke with me this day,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And hath preferr'd thee, if it be preferment

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To leave a rich Jew's service to become

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The follower of so poor a gentleman.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The old proverb is very well parted between my master

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Shylock and you, sir: you have the grace of God, sir, and he hath

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: enough.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Thou speak'st it well. Go, father, with thy son.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Take leave of thy old master, and inquire

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My lodging out. [To a SERVANT] Give him a livery

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: More guarded than his fellows'; see it done.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Father, in. I cannot get a service, no! I have ne'er a

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: tongue in my head! [Looking on his palm] Well; if any man in

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Italy have a fairer table which doth offer to swear upon a book,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: shall have good fortune. Go to; here's a simple line of life:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: here's a small trifle of wives; alas, fifteen wives is nothing;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: a'leven widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one man.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And then to scape drowning thrice, and to be in peril of my life

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: with the edge of a feather-bed; here are simple 'scapes. Well, if

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Fortune be a woman, she's a good wench for this gear. Father,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: come; I'll take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling of an eye.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exeunt LAUNCELOT and OLD GOBBO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: These things being bought and orderly bestow'd,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Return in haste, for I do feast to-night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My best esteem'd acquaintance; hie thee, go.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LEONARDO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My best endeavours shall be done herein.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter GRATIANO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Where's your master?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LEONARDO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Yonder, sir, he walks.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Signior Bassanio!--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Gratiano!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I have suit to you.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You have obtain'd it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You must not deny me: I must go with you to Belmont.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Why, then you must. But hear thee, Gratiano;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Thou art too wild, too rude, and bold of voice;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Parts that become thee happily enough,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And in such eyes as ours appear not faults;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But where thou art not known, why there they show

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Something too liberal. Pray thee, take pain

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To allay with some cold drops of modesty

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behaviour

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I be misconstrued in the place I go to,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And lose my hopes.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Signior Bassanio, hear me:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If I do not put on a sober habit,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Talk with respect, and swear but now and then,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Wear prayer-books in my pocket, look demurely,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nay more, while grace is saying, hood mine eyes

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Thus with my hat, and sigh, and say 'amen';

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Use all the observance of civility,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Like one well studied in a sad ostent

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To please his grandam, never trust me more.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Well, we shall see your bearing.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nay, but I bar to-night; you shall not gauge me

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: By what we do to-night.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: No, that were pity;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I would entreat you rather to put on

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That purpose merriment. But fare you well;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I have some business.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And I must to Lorenzo and the rest;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But we will visit you at supper-time.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exeunt.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SCENE 3. The same. A room in SHYLOCK's house.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter JESSICA and LAUNCELOT.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But fare thee well; there is a ducat for thee;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And, Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Lorenzo, who is thy new master's guest:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Give him this letter; do it secretly.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And so farewell. I would not have my father

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: See me in talk with thee.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Adieu! tears exhibit my tongue. Most beautiful pagan,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: most sweet Jew! If a Christian do not play the knave and get

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: thee, I am much deceived. But, adieu! these foolish drops do

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: something drown my manly spirit; adieu!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Farewell, good Launcelot.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit LAUNCELOT]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Alack, what heinous sin is it in me

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To be asham'd to be my father's child!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But though I am a daughter to his blood,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I am not to his manners. O Lorenzo!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If thou keep promise, I shall end this strife,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Become a Christian and thy loving wife.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SCENE 4. The same. A street

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter GRATIANO, LORENZO, SALARINO, and SALANIO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nay, we will slink away in supper-time,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Disguise us at my lodging, and return

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: All in an hour.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: We have not made good preparation.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SALARINO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: We have not spoke us yet of torch-bearers.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SALANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly order'd,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And better in my mind not undertook.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'Tis now but four o'clock; we have two hours

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To furnish us.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter LAUNCELOT, With a letter.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Friend Launcelot, what's the news?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: An it shall please you to break up this, it shall seem

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: to signify.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I know the hand; in faith, 'tis a fair hand,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And whiter than the paper it writ on

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Is the fair hand that writ.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Love news, in faith.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: By your leave, sir.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Whither goest thou?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Marry, sir, to bid my old master, the Jew, to sup

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: to-night with my new master, the Christian.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Hold, here, take this. Tell gentle Jessica

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I will not fail her; speak it privately.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Go, gentlemen,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit LAUNCELOT]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Will you prepare you for this masque to-night?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I am provided of a torch-bearer.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SALARINO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Ay, marry, I'll be gone about it straight.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SALANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And so will I.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Meet me and Gratiano

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: At Gratiano's lodging some hour hence.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SALARINO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'Tis good we do so.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exeunt SALARINO and SALANIO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Was not that letter from fair Jessica?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I must needs tell thee all. She hath directed

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: How I shall take her from her father's house;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: What gold and jewels she is furnish'd with;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: What page's suit she hath in readiness.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If e'er the Jew her father come to heaven,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It will be for his gentle daughter's sake;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And never dare misfortune cross her foot,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Unless she do it under this excuse,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That she is issue to a faithless Jew.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Come, go with me, peruse this as thou goest;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Fair Jessica shall be my torch-bearer.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exeunt]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SCENE 5. The same. Before SHYLOCK'S house

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter SHYLOCK and LAUNCELOT.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SHYLOCK.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Well, thou shalt see; thy eyes shall be thy judge,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The difference of old Shylock and Bassanio:--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: What, Jessica!--Thou shalt not gormandize,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: As thou hast done with me;--What, Jessica!--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And sleep and snore, and rend apparel out--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Why, Jessica, I say!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Why, Jessica!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SHYLOCK.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Who bids thee call? I do not bid thee call.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Your worship was wont to tell me I could do nothing

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: without bidding.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter JESSICA.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice

text: The prodigal Christian. Jessica, my girl,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: He attendeth here hard by,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To know your answer, whether you'll admit him.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: DUKE OF VENICE.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: With all my heart: some three or four of you

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Go give him courteous conduct to this place.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Meantime, the court shall hear Bellario's letter.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: CLERK.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'Your Grace shall understand that at the receipt

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: of your letter I am very sick; but in the instant that your

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: messenger came, in loving visitation was with me a young doctor

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: of Rome; his name is Balthazar. I acquainted him with the cause

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: in controversy between the Jew and Antonio the merchant; we

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: turn'd o'er many books together; he is furnished with my opinion

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: which, bettered with his own learning,--the greatness whereof I

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: cannot enough commend,--comes with him at my importunity to fill

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: up your Grace's request in my stead. I beseech you let his lack

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: of years be no impediment to let him lack a reverend estimation,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: for I never knew so young a body with so old a head. I leave him

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: to your gracious acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: commendation.'

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: DUKE.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: YOU hear the learn'd Bellario, what he writes;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And here, I take it, is the doctor come.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter PORTIA, dressed like a doctor of laws.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Give me your hand; come you from old Bellario?

text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice

text: DUKE.

title: The Merchant of Venice

title: The Merchant of Venice

text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice

text: Which is the merchant here, and which the Jew?

text: DUKE OF VENICE.

text: Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth.

text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice

text: SHYLOCK.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Of a strange nature is the suit you follow;

text: Yet in such rule that the Venetian law

text: Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.

text: [To ANTONIO.] You stand within his danger, do you not?

title: The Merchant of Venice

text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The quality of mercy is not strain'd;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Upon the place beneath. It is twice blest:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: 'Tis mightiest in the mightiest; it becomes

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The throned monarch better than his crown;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: His sceptre shows the force of temporal power,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The attribute to awe and majesty,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But mercy is above this sceptred sway,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It is enthroned in the hearts of kings,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It is an attribute to God himself;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And earthly power doth then show likest God's

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: When mercy seasons justice. Therefore, Jew,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Though justice be thy plea, consider this,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That in the course of justice none of us

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Should see salvation; we do pray for mercy,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And that same prayer doth teach us all to render

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The deeds of mercy. I have spoke thus much

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To mitigate the justice of thy plea,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Which if thou follow, this strict court of Venice

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there.

text: SHYLOCK.

text: My deeds upon my head! I crave the law,

text: The penalty and forfeit of my bond.

text: PORTIA.

text: Is he not able to discharge the money?

text: Yes; here I tender it for him in the court;

text: Yea, twice the sum; if that will not suffice,

text: I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er

text: If this will not suffice, it must appear

text: That malice bears down truth. And, I beseech you,

text: Wrest once the law to your authority;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To do a great right do a little wrong,

title: The Merchant of Venice

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: When it is paid according to the tenour.

text: It doth appear you are a worthy judge;

text: Hath been most sound; I charge you by the law,

text: Give me your hand, Bassanio: fare you well.!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I wish you well, and so I take my leave.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Dear sir, of force I must attempt you further;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Take some remembrance of us, as a tribute,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Not as fee. Grant me two things, I pray you,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Not to deny me, and to pardon me.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You press me far, and therefore I will yield.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [To ANTONIO]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Give me your gloves, I'll wear them for your sake.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [To BASSANIO]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And, for your love, I'll take this ring from you.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Do not draw back your hand; I'll take no more;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And you in love shall not deny me this.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: This ring, good sir? alas, it is a trifle;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I will not shame myself to give you this.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I will have nothing else but only this;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And now, methinks, I have a mind to it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: There's more depends on this than on the value.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The dearest ring in Venice will I give you,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And find it out by proclamation:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Only for this, I pray you, pardon me.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I see, sir, you are liberal in offers;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You taught me first to beg, and now methinks

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You teach me how a beggar should be answer'd.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And, when she put it on, she made me vow

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That I should neither sell, nor give, nor lose it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That 'scuse serves many men to save their gifts.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And if your wife be not a mad-woman,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And know how well I have deserv'd this ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: She would not hold out enemy for ever

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: For giving it to me. Well, peace be with you!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exeunt PORTIA and NERISSA.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: ANTONIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Let his deservings, and my love withal,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Be valued 'gainst your wife's commandment.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Go, Gratiano, run and overtake him;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Give him the ring, and bring him, if thou canst,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Unto Antonio's house. Away! make haste.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit GRATIANO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Come, you and I will thither presently;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And in the morning early will we both

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Fly toward Belmont. Come, Antonio.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exeunt.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SCENE II.  The same. A street

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter PORTIA and NERISSA.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Inquire the Jew's house out, give him this deed,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And let him sign it; we'll away tonight,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And be a day before our husbands home.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter GRATIANO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Fair sir, you are well o'erta'en.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My Lord Bassanio, upon more advice,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Hath sent you here this ring, and doth entreat

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Your company at dinner.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That cannot be:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: His ring I do accept most thankfully;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And so, I pray you, tell him: furthermore,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I pray you show my youth old Shylock's house.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That will I do.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Sir, I would speak with you.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Aside to PORTIA.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I'll see if I can get my husband's ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Which I did make him swear to keep for ever.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.[To NERISSA]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Thou Mayst, I warrant. We shall have old swearing

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That they did give the rings away to men;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But we'll outface them, and outswear them too.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Away! make haste: thou know'st where I will tarry.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Come, good sir, will you show me to this house?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exeunt.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: ACT V.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: SCENE I. Belmont. The avenue to PORTIA's house.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter LORENZO and JESSICA.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The moon shines bright: in such a night as this,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And they did make no noise, in such a night,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Troilus methinks mounted the Troyan walls,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And sigh'd his soul toward the Grecian tents,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Where Cressid lay that night.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In such a night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Did Thisby fearfully o'ertrip the dew,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And saw the lion's shadow ere himself,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And ran dismay'd away.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In such a night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Stood Dido with a willow in her hand

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Upon the wild sea-banks, and waft her love

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To come again to Carthage.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In such a night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Medea gather'd the enchanted herbs

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That did renew old AEson.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In such a night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Did Jessica steal from the wealthy Jew,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And with an unthrift love did run from Venice

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: As far as Belmont.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In such a night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Did young Lorenzo swear he lov'd her well,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Stealing her soul with many vows of faith,--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And ne'er a true one.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In such a night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Did pretty Jessica, like a little shrew,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Slander her love, and he forgave it her.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I would out-night you, did no body come;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter STEPHANO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: STEPHANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: A friend.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: A friend! What friend? Your name, I pray you, friend?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: STEPHANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Stephano is my name, and I bring word

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My mistress will before the break of day

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Be here at Belmont; she doth stray about

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: For happy wedlock hours.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Who comes with her?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: STEPHANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: None but a holy hermit and her maid.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I pray you, is my master yet return'd?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: He is not, nor we have not heard from him.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But go we in, I pray thee, Jessica,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And ceremoniously let us prepare

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Some welcome for the mistress of the house.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter LAUNCELOT.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT. Sola, sola! wo ha, ho! sola, sola!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Who calls?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Sola! Did you see Master Lorenzo? Master Lorenzo! Sola, sola!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Leave holloaing, man. Here!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Sola! Where? where?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Here!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LAUNCELOT.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Tell him there's a post come from my master with his

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: horn full of good news; my master will be here ere morning.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Sweet soul, let's in, and there expect their coming.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And yet no matter; why should we go in?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My friend Stephano, signify, I pray you,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Within the house, your mistress is at hand;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And bring your music forth into the air.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Exit STEPHANO.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Here will we sit and let the sounds of music

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Creep in our ears; soft stillness and the night

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Become the touches of sweet harmony.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Sit, Jessica: look how the floor of heaven

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: There's not the smallest orb which thou behold'st

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But in his motion like an angel sings,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Still quiring to the young-eyed cherubins;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Such harmony is in immortal souls;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But, whilst this muddy vesture of decay

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter Musicians.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Come, ho! and wake Diana with a hymn;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And draw her home with music.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Music.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: JESSICA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I am never merry when I hear sweet music.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The reason is, your spirits are attentive;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: For do but note a wild and wanton herd,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Or race of youthful and unhandled colts,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neighing loud,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Which is the hot condition of their blood;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Or any air of music touch their ears,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You shall perceive them make a mutual stand,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Their savage eyes turn'd to a modest gaze

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: By the sweet power of music: therefore the poet

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Did feign that Orpheus drew trees, stones, and floods;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Since nought so stockish, hard, and full of rage,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But music for the time doth change his nature.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The man that hath no music in himself,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nor is not mov'd with concord of sweet sounds,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The motions of his spirit are dull as night,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And his affections dark as Erebus.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Let no such man be trusted. Mark the music.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter PORTIA and NERISSA, at a distance.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That light we see is burning in my hall.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: How far that little candle throws his beams!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: So shines a good deed in a naughty world.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: When the moon shone, we did not see the candle.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: So doth the greater glory dim the less:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: A substitute shines brightly as a king

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Until a king be by, and then his state

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Empties itself, as doth an inland brook

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Into the main of waters. Music! hark!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It is your music, madam, of the house.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nothing is good, I see, without respect:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: When neither is attended; and I think

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The nightingale, if she should sing by day,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: When every goose is cackling, would be thought

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: No better a musician than the wren.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: How many things by season season'd are

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To their right praise and true perfection!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Peace, ho! The moon sleeps with Endymion,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And would not be awak'd!

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Music ceases.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That is the voice,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Or I am much deceiv'd, of Portia.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: By the bad voice.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO. Dear lady, welcome home.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: We have been praying for our husbands' welfare,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Are they return'd?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Madam, they are not yet;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But there is come a messenger before,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To signify their coming.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Go in, Nerissa:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Give order to my servants that they take

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: No note at all of our being absent hence;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nor you, Lorenzo; Jessica, nor you.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [A tucket sounds.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: LORENZO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Your husband is at hand; I hear his trumpet.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: We are no tell-tales, madam, fear you not.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: This night methinks is but the daylight sick;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It looks a little paler; 'tis a day

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Such as the day is when the sun is hid.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: [Enter BASSANIO, ANTONIO, GRATIANO, and their Followers.]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: We should hold day with the Antipodes,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If you would walk in absence of the sun.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Let me give light, but let me not be light,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: For a light wife doth make a heavy husband,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And never be Bassanio so for me:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But God sort all! You are welcome home, my lord.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I thank you, madam; give welcome to my friend:

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: This is the man, this is Antonio,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To whom I am so infinitely bound.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You should in all sense be much bound to him,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: For, as I hear, he was much bound for you.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: ANTONIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: No more than I am well acquitted of.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Sir, you are very welcome to our house.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: It must appear in other ways than words,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO. [To NERISSA]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: In faith, I gave it to the judge's clerk.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Would he were gelt that had it, for my part,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Since you do take it, love, so much at heart.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: A quarrel, ho, already! What's the matter?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That she did give me, whose posy was

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: For all the world like cutlers' poetry

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Upon a knife, 'Love me, and leave me not.'

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: What talk you of the posy, or the value?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You swore to me, when I did give it you,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That you would wear it till your hour of death,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And that it should lie with you in your grave;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You should have been respective and have kept it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Gave it a judge's clerk! No, God's my judge,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: The clerk will ne'er wear hair on's face that had it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: He will, an if he live to be a man.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Ay, if a woman live to be a man.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Now, by this hand, I gave it to a youth,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: A kind of boy, a little scrubbed boy

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: No higher than thyself, the judge's clerk;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: A prating boy that begg'd it as a fee;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I could not for my heart deny it him.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You were to blame,--I must be plain with you,--

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: To part so slightly with your wife's first gift,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I gave my love a ring, and made him swear

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Never to part with it, and here he stands,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That the world masters. Now, in faith, Gratiano,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: An 'twere to me, I should be mad at it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.[Aside]

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Why, I were best to cut my left hand off,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And swear I lost the ring defending it.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: GRATIANO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Unto the judge that begg'd it, and indeed

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Deserv'd it too; and then the boy, his clerk,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: That took some pains in writing, he begg'd mine;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And neither man nor master would take aught

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: But the two rings.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: What ring gave you, my lord?

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Not that, I hope, which you receiv'd of me.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If I could add a lie unto a fault,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: I would deny it; but you see my finger

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Hath not the ring upon it; it is gone.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Even so void is your false heart of truth;

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: By heaven, I will ne'er come in your bed

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Until I see the ring.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: NERISSA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Nor I in yours

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Till I again see mine.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: BASSANIO.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Sweet Portia,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If you did know to whom I gave the ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If you did know for whom I gave the ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And would conceive for what I gave the ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: And how unwillingly I left the ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: When nought would be accepted but the ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: You would abate the strength of your displeasure.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: PORTIA.

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: If you had known the virtue of the ring,

title: The Merchant of Venice
text: Or half her worthiness that gave the ring,
